node.text:
Excerpt from Huberman Lab Podcast interview with Dr. Lex Fridman, Ph.D. @lexfridman 
-
Here Lex describes how humans and machines of all kinds- even a refrigerator, can interact with each other at numerous meaningful levels. Most people think of machines having knowledge of us as a negative thing. However, there’s actually the potential for great depth and growth and vastly improved self-understanding by way of engineered human-machine relationships. 
-
If you’re interested in how the human mind works, and what creates empathy, power, pain, and love, you’ll definitely want to check out this discussion with Lex. He parses it all using unparalleled logic and clarity. 
-
Link to full episode in all formats- video and/or audio, in my profile bio. 
Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @mitscience @lexfridman 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #brain #neuralnetworks #engineering #robot #robotics #food #learning #refrigerator #passion  #power #love

node.text:
New data published in Cell reveal that ingesting fermented foods daily promotes a healthy gut microbiome by increasing microbiota diversity, and supports general health by reducing inflammation and other factors that can lead to autoimmune and mood disorders. Surprisingly, excessive fiber disrupted some of these same systems in unhealthy ways.
-
Here I describe that study and provided a (very general) tutorial of how the gut brain axis works and its relationship to things like leaky gut, and the dopamine systems in the brain.
-
Please put any questions you have in the comments section below this post. 
A new episode of the Huberman Lab Podcast comes out tomorrow. It’s a guest episode. You can find it and all other episodes at hubermanlab.com or by going to the link in my bio. All episodes are time stamped and captioned in English and Spanish. 
Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress 
_
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #gut #brain #inflammation #microbiome #fermented #fiber #protein #leakygut #leakygutsyndrome #dopamine #learn #mechanism #acid #alkaline #sugar

node.text:
There are 3 quality-science supported ways to enhance rates of learning and retention of the learned information. I describe those 3, how they work, and the references here. 
-
For more details on these protocols & how to incorporate them into specific forms of learning such as creative learning, math, languages, or physical skills please see/listen to the most recent episode of the Huberman Lab Podcast (the link in my instagram bio or simply go to: hubermanlab.com) 
-
Please put any questions you have about these protocols in the comments
section below this post. As always thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress 
_
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #learn #dopamine #focus #neuroplasticity #noise #NSDR #hippocampus #cortex #factsnothacks

node.text:
(Excerpt from the final question @timferriss asked @hubermanlab on The Tim Ferriss Show Podcast). 
-
Tim asked me what I would put on a billboard. Not an easy choice, but given a billboard has two sides, this was my answer.
_
The first maxim was written on the Oracle at Delphi, long ago, which speaks to the fact that the human nervous system has likely not evolved much since then and that people were grappling with many of the same issues they do today. I believe this maxim still holds value as a rudder for adaptive change. 

The second maxim stems from our understanding of the way the brain, spinal cord and body are connected - in reciprocal fashion. 
_
Detailed protocols, direct-to-source links and show notes from our conversation can be found by following the link in profile bio @timferriss or by searching Tim’s blog: https://tim.blog/2021/07/06/andrew-huberman/
-
Topics we covered include: sleep, hypnosis for neuroplasticity (and a zero-cost but highly valuable resource for research supported hypnosis), hormone augmentation, Olympic burritos, psychedelics, exploring your mind as a dedicated practice through journaling or therapy, the value of formal rigorous coursework, vagus nerve myths and truths, insula interoception, depression, loss, wins, happiness, love of dogs and lots and lots of tools and practices we each use daily. 
-
Please put any questions you might have about the episode in the comments section below. Thank you Tim for hosting me and thank you all for your interest in science! 
_
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience 
-

node.text:
_
One of the most frequent questions I get is how to enhance focus & learning. In the most recent episode of the Huberman Lab Podcast I describe  peer reviewed studies showing that listening to white noise can be beneficial for learning. One of those studies points to enhanced release of dopamine as a partial explanation for this effect. Please note white noise may have detrimental effects on the very young developing brain and auditory system. I describe that work in the podcast episode as well.
-
For more on enhancing focus, learning and dopamine and the science of the auditory and vestibular systems, see (or listen to) the most recent Huberman Lab Podcast episode by following the link in my profile bio. 
-
Everything is time-stamped and captioned in English and Spanish. please put any questions you have in the comments section below this post or on YouTube. Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience 
-

node.text:
There are science supported ways to learn faster. Here I describe how introducing very brief gaps of rest during skill learning can enhance rates of skill acquisition and retention.  New data show that during the rest periods the hippocampus and cortex repeat the exact same pattern of firing that is  present during the actual performance of the skill, but at 20 times the speed (Cohen and colleagues, Cell Reports 2021).
-
I’ve discussed before how generating maximum number of repetitions per unit time is the key for learning. These new findings indicate we can generate far more repetitions through the introduction of properly structured micro-rest.
-
Details on the study, the specific protocol, and much more - including sound effects on learning and enhancing dopamine release are covered in the Huberman Lab Podcast Episode that comes out tomorrow morning Monday, 6 AM Pacific time. 
_
The podcast can be found on Apple Spotify or YouTube or simply by following the link in my profile bio. All episodes are captioned in English and Spanish and time stamped for specific topics so you can find the information you want.
_
Please put your questions and comments in the comments section below this post. For suggestions about future podcast episodes, please put those in the comments section on YouTube. And thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress 
-

node.text:
Excerpt from the most recent episode of The Huberman Lab Podcast with guest Dr Karl Deisseroth, MD, PhD. 
-
Dr. Deisseroth is a psychiatrist and research scientist bioengineer @stanford.med He treats patients suffering from depression, ADHD, OCD, schizophrenia, autism, borderline, bipolar and other disorders of the mind. His  lab develops state-of-the-art tools to parse the neural circuits in the healthy and diseased mind, and they develop novel treatments based on bioengineering proteins from algae that can be used to control human neurons in specific ways.
-
Here we discuss how the eyes are a rich source of information about brain state and how psychiatrists use that information to diagnose various conditions involving mood and social interactions. 
-
To hear the full episode on Apple or Spotify or to watch the episode on YouTube follow the link in my profile bio. Please put any questions you have in the comments section below this post or on YouTube. And be sure to check out Dr. Deisseroth’s amazing new book “Projections: a story of human emotions” it is available on Amazon, audible etc.
-
As always, thank you for your interest in science! 
_
@stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @penguinrandomhouse 
-

node.text:
Excerpt from Huberman Lab Podcast with guest Dr Karl Deisseroth, MD, PhD. 
-
Dr. Deisseroth is a board certified Psychiatrist and runs a bioengineering laboratory @stanford.med were they are developing tools and treatments for diagnosing and treating disorders of the mind. 
-
Here we discuss some of the similarities and differences between phone checking, ADHD, OCD and how these disorders are diagnosed. 
-
During the episode we discuss many disorders of the mind, their current treatments, and the groundbreaking work Dr. deisseroths laboratory and clinic are doing to diagnose and treat nervous system illnesses. 
-
You can find the link to the episode in my profile bio. Please put any questions or thoughts you have regarding this topic or the episode in the comments section below this post or on YouTube. We use your feedback to inform future guests and content. Thank you for your interest in science!

node.text:
Dopamine is what’s called a neuromodulator. Meaning it changes the likelihood that certain brain circuits will be active and that others will not. Most of us associate dopamine with pleasure but in fact it’s more closely related to our sense of desire and motivation. Indeed, in the absence of dopamine animals and humans can still experience pleasure but they are less motivated to seek out any form of pleasure that requires challenge.
-
This short clip from my recent guest appearance on @dhrupurohit podcast explains the experimental evidence.  To hear our full discussion about focus, tools for focus, and motivation, see Ep 224 of The Dhru Purohit Podcast. You can find it in the profile link @dhrupurohit 
_
And if you’re interested in tools specifically related to increasing dopamine and motivation, I discuss those and the underlying biology in Episode 12 of The Huberman Lab Podcast (all formats can be found at hubermanlab.com or by following link in my profile bio here on Instagram).
-
Please put any questions you have in the comments section below and thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @dhrupurohit @cellpress

node.text:
The mere act of inhaling has been shown to increase arousal and alertness in the brain, as well as our depth of focus and our ability to learn. Remarkably, this occurs independently of the changes caused to oxygen and carbon dioxide. It is also not limited to learning of olfactory information. This brief 2 minute video explains the science. 
-
For details on the protocols and for more information about how inhales and specific chemicals impact our cognition and behavior, hormones and physiology, see episode 25 of the Huberman lab Podcast which is out now, on all audio format and on YouTube. 
_
You can find a link to it and links to all resources mentioned (papers protocols etc) at hubermanlab.com or by tapping the link in my profile bio. 
-
Later this week I will hold a live discussion here on Instagram to discuss any questions from this episode. Meanwhile please put your questions you have in the comments section below. And thank you for your interest in science! 
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @nature_the_journal @weizmanninstitute

node.text:
There are strong neural mechanisms linking our head posture, our eyes and whether or not they are open, closed or partially open, blinking and alertness. This brief video explains the basic logic.
-
The simple take away is: if you want to be more alert: keep that chin up, eyes up, eyes open. You might even consider where you place your computer screen relative to where you’re sitting or standing. If you’re staring down at your phone much of the day you are not doing yourself any favors with respect to cognition or alertness. Hold at eye level. 
-
Details on the science and 12 other protocols related to vision, mood, enhancing visual focus and mental focus, all science supported and zero cost were covered in the latest episode (24) of the Huberman Lab Podcast. See the link in my profile bio for audio and video formats. 
-
Please place your questions in the comments section below. New episodes of the Huberman Lab podcast out every Monday. And thank you for your interest in science! 
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience

node.text:
People have speculated for centuries that hallucinations were caused by over activation of the visual brain or from increased connectivity in the brain. That is not the case at all. In fact, the opposite is true. Visual hallucinations are the consequence of under activation of the eyes and brain from light. This video explains the underlying science.
_
Note: There are many online claims that visual hallucinations are caused by the release of DMT from the pineal gland. That is also not true. Indeed, it’s pure fiction. The pineal does not manufacture DMT at meaningful concentrations. The chemical basis of hallucinations is distinct from the pineal and from endogenous DMT. More on pineal and hallucination biology in a subsequent post.
-
For more on vision, and how to improve and reinforce your vision regardless of whether or not you see well already see hubermanlab.com for link to the full episode and vision training videos (zero-cost). Link is in profile bio too. 
-
Please questions in the comment section below and thank you for your interest in science!
_
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @uoforegonn 
_
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #pineal #myths #facts #halkucinations #mindseye #darkness #vision #learn

node.text:
Excerpt from Huberman Lab Podcast interview with Dr. Lex Fridman, Ph.D. @lexfridman 
-
Here Lex describes how humans and machines of all kinds- even a refrigerator, can interact with each other at numerous meaningful levels. Most people think of machines having knowledge of us as a negative thing. However, there’s actually the potential for great depth and growth and vastly improved self-understanding by way of engineered human-machine relationships. 
-
If you’re interested in how the human mind works, and what creates empathy, power, pain, and love, you’ll definitely want to check out this discussion with Lex. He parses it all using unparalleled logic and clarity. 
-
Link to full episode in all formats- video and/or audio, in my profile bio. 
Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @mitscience @lexfridman 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #brain #neuralnetworks #engineering #robot #robotics #food #learning #refrigerator #passion  #power #love

node.text:
NEW HUBERMAN LAB PODCAST EPISODE: DR. LEX FRIDMAN, PhD. 
-
This weeks episode of the Huberman Lab Podcast features Dr. Lex Fridman, Ph.D. @lexfridman — a scientist working in the fields of artificial intelligence, robotics, and machine learning. He is also the host of the Lex Fridman Podcast. 
-
We discuss big questions such as “what is intelligence?” and “what creates and builds relationships?” and “how does the mind work to solve hard problems?” 
We also address the basis of romantic relationships, friendship, human-animal and human-robot relationships. Lex also gave us a unique window into the incredible technologies he is building for all of us to benefit from. Lex is a true visionary. To hear him speak is to learn. I’m honored to call him a friend. Enjoy! 
-
You can find the podcast on all major platforms: YouTube, Apple, Spotify, at the link in my profile bio or by going to: hubermanlab.com/dr-lex-fridman-machines-creativity-and-love/
-
Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @mitscience @lexfridman 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #brain #neuralnetworks #engineering #russian #robot #robotics #learning #refrigerator #dogs #hedgehog #romance #jujitsu #bjj #power #love

node.text:
New data published in Cell reveal that ingesting fermented foods daily promotes a healthy gut microbiome by increasing microbiota diversity, and supports general health by reducing inflammation and other factors that can lead to autoimmune and mood disorders. Surprisingly, excessive fiber disrupted some of these same systems in unhealthy ways.
-
Here I describe that study and provided a (very general) tutorial of how the gut brain axis works and its relationship to things like leaky gut, and the dopamine systems in the brain.
-
Please put any questions you have in the comments section below this post. 
A new episode of the Huberman Lab Podcast comes out tomorrow. It’s a guest episode. You can find it and all other episodes at hubermanlab.com or by going to the link in my bio. All episodes are time stamped and captioned in English and Spanish. 
Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress 
_
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #gut #brain #inflammation #microbiome #fermented #fiber #protein #leakygut #leakygutsyndrome #dopamine #learn #mechanism #acid #alkaline #sugar

node.text:
THE SCIENCE of “DAD BOD”: PROLACTIN 
-
Research data from animals and humans show that some unknown chemical from the pregnant females triggers elevated levels of prolactin (a decreases testosterone) in the father. That prolactin in turn causes retention of body fat, presumably as an enhanced resource for long nights of no sleep associated with multiple feedings of infants throughout the 24 hour cycle. Hence, “Dad Bod”.
-
Previously it was just assumed that men eat more food around the time when they expect or have recently had newborns but this is not the case and often the opposite is true. 
-
@joerogan and I discussed hormones and the brain as they relate to aggression, mating, body composition, dominance and more on a recent episode of @joeroganexperience podcast. You can find it on Spotify. 
-
Please put any questions you have in the comments section below this post and thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciência #neurociência #testosterone #prolactin #lactation #dopamine #dadbod #fat #adipose #sleep #parenting

node.text:
SCIENCE-SUPPORTED DAILY TOOLS FOR FOCUS, LEARNING, CREATIVITY, SLEEP, PHYSICAL STRENGTH & ENDURANCE, BRAIN & BODILY HEALTH •
-
Many people have asked for description of the most powerful science-based tools and how they can be incorporated into a daily, weekly and yearly routine. In this episode I cover everything from waking until sleep and even protocols to use during sleep. I also cover how to reset these routines quickly after a weekend, an illness or other disruption, and variations based on individual needs. If you’re looking for real-life actionable protocols, this is the episode to watch/listen to. 
-
Everything is time-stamped and listed out as a different numbered protocol in the captions on YouTube, as well as on Apple on Spotify. Captions are in English and Spanish. 
all formats are easy to fine by just going to the link in my profile bio: hubermanlab.com
_
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post. You can expect an Instagram Live later this week where I will review and answer those questions. 
As always, thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress

node.text:
(Excerpt from the final question @timferriss asked @hubermanlab on The Tim Ferriss Show Podcast). 
-
Tim asked me what I would put on a billboard. Not an easy choice, but given a billboard has two sides, this was my answer.
_
The first maxim was written on the Oracle at Delphi, long ago, which speaks to the fact that the human nervous system has likely not evolved much since then and that people were grappling with many of the same issues they do today. I believe this maxim still holds value as a rudder for adaptive change. 

The second maxim stems from our understanding of the way the brain, spinal cord and body are connected - in reciprocal fashion. 
_
Detailed protocols, direct-to-source links and show notes from our conversation can be found by following the link in profile bio @timferriss or by searching Tim’s blog: https://tim.blog/2021/07/06/andrew-huberman/
-
Topics we covered include: sleep, hypnosis for neuroplasticity (and a zero-cost but highly valuable resource for research supported hypnosis), hormone augmentation, Olympic burritos, psychedelics, exploring your mind as a dedicated practice through journaling or therapy, the value of formal rigorous coursework, vagus nerve myths and truths, insula interoception, depression, loss, wins, happiness, love of dogs and lots and lots of tools and practices we each use daily. 
-
Please put any questions you might have about the episode in the comments section below. Thank you Tim for hosting me and thank you all for your interest in science! 
_
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciência #neurociencia #oracle #brain #insula #neuroplasticity #sleep #mentalhealth #hypnosis #testosterone #estrogen #vagusnerve #focus #creativity #autonomicnervoussystem

node.text:
TIM FERRISS PODCAST WITH 
DR. ANDREW HUBERMAN: SLEEP, PERFORMANCE & TESTOSTERONE •
-
I recently had the pleasure of being hosted by @timferriss on The Tim Ferriss Show. We discussed a large range of topics and resources (all linked) for: sleep, cortisol regulation, neuroplasticity, supplements, psychedelics, psychoanalysis, favorite books, and poetry. We also discussed some previously untold adventures in personal development, and near-death experiences. It was an honor and a pleasure to be a guest. Thank you Tim! 
-
You can find the episode (and extensive resources) at the link in bio @timferriss or by going to The Tim Ferriss Show on Apple, Spotify etc or at: https://tim.blog/2021/07/06/andrew-huberman/ 
-

node.text:
_
One of the most frequent questions I get is how to enhance focus & learning. In the most recent episode of the Huberman Lab Podcast I describe  peer reviewed studies showing that listening to white noise can be beneficial for learning. One of those studies points to enhanced release of dopamine as a partial explanation for this effect. Please note white noise may have detrimental effects on the very young developing brain and auditory system. I describe that work in the podcast episode as well.
-
For more on enhancing focus, learning and dopamine and the science of the auditory and vestibular systems, see (or listen to) the most recent Huberman Lab Podcast episode by following the link in my profile bio. 
-
Everything is time-stamped and captioned in English and Spanish. please put any questions you have in the comments section below this post or on YouTube. Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience
